examples: All horses are animals, but not all animals are horses.
Cars were coming from all directions (= every direction).
All the people you invited are coming.
All my plants have died.
All five men are hard workers.
All wood tends to shrink.
You've had all the fun and I've had all the hard work.
All this mail must be answered.
He has lost all his money.

meanings.def: used with singular nouns showing something has been happening for a whole period of time
examples: He's worked hard all year.
She was unemployed for all that time.
In all honesty (= being as honest as I can), I can't agree.

meanings.def: consisting or appearing to consist of one thing only
examples: The magazine was all advertisements.
She was all smiles (= smiling a lot).
He denied all knowledge of the crime.
I'm bored by history—dates and battles and all that stuff.
For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.

meanings.def: used to say that something is not important or of no interest or value to you/somebody
examples: For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.
He doesn't sing all that well.

meanings.def: not as much as has been suggested
examples: They're not as rich as all that.
We didn't play particularly well, but we didn't do as badly as all that.
I've locked myself out. Of all the stupid things to do!

meanings.def: used to express surprise because somebody/something seems the least likely person, example, etc.
examples: I didn't think you, of all people, would become a vegetarian.

meanings.def: in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

idioms.idiom: and all that (jazz, rubbish, stuff, etc.)
idioms.def: and other similar things
examples: I'm bored by history—dates and battles and all that stuff.

idioms.def: despite
examples: For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.
For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.

idioms.idiom: not all that good, well, etc.
idioms.def: not particularly good, well, etc.
examples: He doesn't sing all that well.

idioms.idiom: not as bad(ly), etc. as all that
idioms.def: not as much as has been suggested
examples: They're not as rich as all that.
We didn't play particularly well, but we didn't do as badly as all that.

idioms.def: used to express anger
examples: I've locked myself out. Of all the stupid things to do!

idioms.def: used to express surprise because somebody/something seems the least likely person, example, etc.
examples: I didn't think you, of all people, would become a vegetarian.

idioms.idiom: on/from all sides | on/from every side
idioms.def: in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.
All of the food has gone.
They've eaten all of it.
They've eaten it all.
I invited some of my colleagues but not all.
Not all of them were invited.
All of them enjoyed the party.
They all enjoyed it.
His last movie was best of all.
All I want is peace and quiet.
It was all that I had.
We have invited fifty people altogether.
I am not altogether convinced by this argument.
Can you put your books all together in this box?
Let’s sing ‘Happy Birthday’. All together now!
Above all, keep in touch.

meanings.def: despite what has been said or expected
examples: So you made it after all!

meanings.def: used when you are explaining something, or giving a reason
examples: He should have paid. He suggested it, after all.
They gave their all (= fought and died) in the war.
All in all it had been a great success.

meanings.def: having two or more uses, functions, etc.
examples: It's a corkscrew and bottle-opener all in one.
She jumped into the river, clothes and all (= with her clothes on).
‘I'm freezing.’ ‘Yeah, me and all.’

meanings.def: used to emphasize how extreme a quality or action is
examples: He's as crazy as all get out!
We rushed like all get out.

meanings.def: in any way; to any degree
examples: I didn't enjoy it at all.
For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.

meanings.def: used to say that something is not important or of no interest or value to you/somebody
examples: For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.
There were twelve of us in all for dinner.
That's £25.40 in all.

meanings.def: used as a polite reply to an expression of thanks
examples: ‘Thanks very much for your help.’ ‘Not at all, it was a pleasure.’

idioms.def: most important of all; especially
examples: Above all, keep in touch.

idioms.def: despite what has been said or expected
examples: So you made it after all!
He should have paid. He suggested it, after all.

idioms.def: everything you have
examples: They gave their all (= fought and died) in the war.

idioms.def: when everything is considered
examples: All in all it had been a great success.

idioms.def: having two or more uses, functions, etc.
examples: It's a corkscrew and bottle-opener all in one.

idioms.def: also; included; in addition
examples: She jumped into the river, clothes and all (= with her clothes on).
‘I'm freezing.’ ‘Yeah, me and all.’

idioms.def: used to emphasize how extreme a quality or action is
examples: He's as crazy as all get out!
We rushed like all get out.

idioms.def: in any way; to any degree
examples: I didn't enjoy it at all.

idioms.idiom: end it all | end your life
idioms.def: to kill yourself
despite
examples: For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.
For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.

idioms.def: as a total
examples: There were twelve of us in all for dinner.
That's £25.40 in all.

idioms.def: used as a polite reply to an expression of thanks
examples: ‘Thanks very much for your help.’ ‘Not at all, it was a pleasure.’

idioms.idiom: put an end to yourself | put an end to it all
idioms.def: to kill yourself

examples: She was dressed all in white.
He lives all alone.
The coffee went all over my skirt.
She was all excited.
Now don't get all upset about it.

meanings.def: used to show that something is more than you would like
examples: I'm all too aware of the problems.
The end of the trip came all too soon.
The score was four all.

meanings.def: all the time; from the beginning
examples: I realized it was in my pocket all along.

meanings.def: in every way; in all respects
examples: a good performance all around
She bought drinks all around.
We'll have to work all the harder with two people off sick.
Her difficult childhood makes her achievements all the more remarkable.
The party was all but over when we arrived.
It was all but impossible to read his writing.
All but one of the plates were damaged.
At the end of the race he felt all in.
The trip cost £750 all in.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an amount, a size, etc. usually when it is very small
examples: It must be all of 100 metres to the car!
We looked all over for the ring.

meanings.def: what you would expect of the person mentioned
examples: That sounds like my sister all over.

meanings.def: in every way; in all respects
examples: a good performance all round
She bought drinks all round.

meanings.def: having a healthy mind; thinking clearly
examples: He behaves very oddly at times—I don't think he's quite all there.

meanings.def: used to say what the most important aspect of something is
examples: It's all about money these days.

meanings.def: to believe strongly that something should be done
examples: They're all for saving money where they can.

meanings.def: to show a lot of interest in or enthusiasm for somebody
examples: He was all over her at the party.

meanings.def: to be very attractive or impressive
examples: He thinks he's all that.

meanings.def: to be the end for somebody
examples: It looks as though it's all up with us now (= we are ruined, have no further chances, etc.).

idioms.def: all the time; from the beginning
examples: I realized it was in my pocket all along.

idioms.def: in every way; in all respects
examples: a good performance all around
She bought drinks all around.

idioms.idiom: all the better, harder, more, etc.
idioms.def: so much better, harder, etc.
examples: We'll have to work all the harder with two people off sick.
Her difficult childhood makes her achievements all the more remarkable.

idioms.def: almost
examples: The party was all but over when we arrived.
It was all but impossible to read his writing.
All but one of the plates were damaged.

idioms.def: physically tired
examples: At the end of the race he felt all in.
The trip cost £750 all in.

idioms.def: used to emphasize an amount, a size, etc. usually when it is very small
examples: It must be all of 100 metres to the car!

idioms.def: everywhere
examples: We looked all over for the ring.
That sounds like my sister all over.

idioms.def: in every way; in all respects
examples: a good performance all round
She bought drinks all round.

idioms.def: having a healthy mind; thinking clearly
examples: He behaves very oddly at times—I don't think he's quite all there.

idioms.def: used to say what the most important aspect of something is
examples: It's all about money these days.

idioms.idiom: be all for something/for doing something
idioms.def: to believe strongly that something should be done
examples: They're all for saving money where they can.

idioms.def: to show a lot of interest in or enthusiasm for somebody
examples: He was all over her at the party.

idioms.def: to be very attractive or impressive
examples: He thinks he's all that.

idioms.def: to be the end for somebody
examples: It looks as though it's all up with us now (= we are ruined, have no further chances, etc.).
an all-British cast
an all-inclusive price
all-important
all-powerful
